Package nl.naturalis.yokete.template

Class Template

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.yokete.template.Template
  • public class Template
extends Object
    A Template captures the result of parsing a template file. It provides access to the constituent parts of a text template: template variables, nested templates and literal text. Template instances are immutable, expensive-to-create and heavy-weight objects. They should be cached (for example as a static final field in your controller or resource class) and reused for as long as the web application is up. Creating a new Template instance for each new request would be very inefficient.
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Field Detail

      • ROOT_TEMPLATE_NAME

        public static final String ROOT_TEMPLATE_NAME
        The name of the root template: "@ROOT". This is the Template that is explicitly instantiated by calling one of the parse(...) methods. The templates nested inside it get their name from the contents of the file (e.g. ~%%begin:invoices% or ~%%include:invoices:/templates/invoice-table.html%).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • parse

        public static Template parse​(String source)
                      throws ParseException
        Parses the specified source text into a Template instance. Only use this constructor if the template does not include other templates (using ~%%include:path/to/other/source/file%).
        Parameters:
        source - The source text for the Template
        Returns:
        a new Template instance
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • parse

        public static Template parse​(Class<?> clazz,
                             String source)
                      throws ParseException
        Parses the specified source text into a Template instance. The specified class will be used to include other template files by calling getResourceAsStream upon it.
        Parameters:
        clazz - Any Class object that provides access to the included tempate files by calling getResourceAsStream on it
        source - The source text for the Template
        Returns:
        a new Template instance
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • parse

        public static Template parse​(Class<?> clazz,
                             Path path)
                      throws ParseException
        Loads the template file at the specified location by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream, path and parses its contents into a Template instance. The specified class will also be used to include other template files.
        Parameters:
        clazz - Any Class object that provides access to the tempate files by calling getResourceAsStream on it
        path - The location of the template file
        Returns:
        a new Template instance
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • getName

        public String getName()
        Returns the name of the template.
        Returns:
        The name of the template

      • getPath

        public Path getPath()
        If the template was created by specifying the location of a template file, this method returns the path, else null. In other words, for included templates this method returns a non-null value. For nested templates this method returns null. For the root template the return value depends on which parse method was used to instantiate the template.
        Returns:

      • getParts

        public List<Part> getParts()
        Returns the constituent parts of the template. A template falls apart in literal text, template variables, nested templates and included templates. The returned List is immutable.
        Returns:
        The constituent parts of the template file

      • getVarPartIndices

        public Map<String,​nl.naturalis.common.collection.IntList> getVarPartIndices()
        Tells you which parts in the parts list contain variables. One variable may occur multiple times in the same template. Therefore multiple parts may contain the same variable. Hence the returned Map maps each variable name to a list of List indices. The returned Map is immutable.
        Returns:

      • getVariableNames

        public Set<String> getVariableNames()
        Returns the names of all variables.
        Returns:
        The names of all variables

      • countVariables

        public int countVariables()
        Returns the sum total of all variables in the template. N.B. not the number of unique variable names.
        Returns:
        The sum total of all variables in the template

      • getTemplatePartIndices

        public Map<String,​Integer> getTemplatePartIndices()
        Tells you which parts in the parts list contain templates (nested or included). The returned Map maps each template name to exactly one List index (template names must be unique within the parent template). The returned Map is immutable.
        Returns:

      • getTemplateNames

        public Set<String> getTemplateNames()
        Returns the names of all nested and included templates.
        Returns:
        The names of all nested and included templates

      • countTemplates

        public int countTemplates()

      • getTemplate

        public Template getTemplate​(String name)
        Returns the nested or included template identified by the specified name. This method throws an IllegalArgumentException if no nested or included template has the specified name.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the nested template
        Returns:
        A Template nested inside this Template

      • getAllNames

        public Set<String> getAllNames()
        Returns all names found in the template (variable names, nested template names, included template names).
        Returns:
        All names found in the template

      • getTextPartIndices

        public nl.naturalis.common.collection.IntList getTextPartIndices()
        Tells you which parts in the parts list contain literal text. The returned IntList contains the List indexes of those parts. The returned IntList is immutable.
        Returns:
        An IntList of all part indexes where literal text can be found
